awd_titl_txt: Laboratory Studies of O(1D) Processes Important in the Upper Atmosphere
awd_abstract_narration: The investigators will conduct a series of experiments on atmospherically important processes involving oxygen atoms in the singlet D state [O(1D)]. First, they will measure the rate coefficient for the collisional removal of O(1D) by oxygen atoms in the triple D state [O(3D)] and its temperature dependence in the range 300 to 1000 K. Recent laboratory studies at room temperature have indicated that relaxation by oxygen atoms is the most significant process controlling the intensity of the 630 nm red line emission at altitudes 200-300 km. The study will yield the first set of laboratory measurements at the relevant high temperatures. The investigators will also investigate the temperature dependence of other reaction rates important for understanding atmospheric oxygen emissions. These laboratory experiments are essential for improving the currently incomplete understanding of ionospheric red-line emission, allowing for better modeling and quantification of molecular oxygen Atmospheric Band emissions, and elucidating the role of oxygen atom energy transfer in the altitude range 120-400 km. Also, knowledge of the rate coefficient for the collisional removal of O(1D) by O(3P) allows the correct interpretation and analysis of the O(1D) emissions. These results will enhance the scientific return of ionospheric heating experiments by enabling a correct interpretation and quantification of the 630-nm red line emission. The rate coefficients to be measured are relevant to both calm and perturbed atmospheric conditions. This work should also help improve understanding of satellite drag and the interpretation of results from incoherent scatter radar measurements. Energy balance in the upper atmosphere is key to modeling the Earth as a system. Application of basic chemistry and physics to the study of collisional energy transfer processes on a fundamental level is also critical for understanding the operation of lasers, especially high-power chemical lasers. Finally, the study will contribute to training, mentoring, and research experiences of postdoctoral fellows and summer undergraduate students.
org_div_long_name: Division of Atmospheric and Geospace Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This project was devoted to laboratory experiments that help us understand energy transfer between energetically excited oxygen atoms and molecules in the Earth's upper atmospheric region that is called the ionosphere or lower thermosphere (above approximately 100 km).

Our experiments investigated collisions between excited oxygen atoms, O(1D), interacting with molecular oxygen, molecular nitrogen, and with ground-state oxygen atoms. We determined how fast the energy transfer takes place and how these processes depend on the temperature. Previous laboratory measurements were either missing from the literature or inconsistent. We also studied the relaxation of excited molecular oxygen, O2(b, v = 1), by oxygen atoms and determined the relative yield for its production following collisions of O(1D) with O2. The latter yield and its high-temperature value was one of our most significant results; we found that approximately 80% of O(1D) collisions with O2 generate O2(b, v = 1). This finding represents a major revision to previous literature values and recommended model inputs that significantly underestimated this yield.

The results of our laboratory experiments are essential input for atmospheric models and for a reliable quantitative interpretation of the atomic and molecular oxygen emissions observed in the ionosphere in the altitude range 100–400 km.

This project provided research training and educational opportunities for four (4) summer undergraduate students and one post-doctoral fellow. The undergraduate students participated at our NSF Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site.
